@@ -0,0 +1,91 @@
+'use strict';
+var USERNAME = process.env.GITHUB_USER;
+var PASSWORD = process.env.GITHUB_PASSWORD;
+var cheerio = require('cheerio');
+var childProcess = require('child_process');
+var CookieJar = require('./cookieJar');
+var jar = new CookieJar();
+
+/**
+ * Scrape github login page
+ * @return {Object} Object containeing two keys: headers (a string) and body (also a string)
+ */
+var githubLogin = function() {
+  var output = childProcess.execSync('curl -v -L https://github.com/login 2>&1').toString().split('<!DOCTYPE html>');
+  return {
+    headers: output[0],
+    body: output[1]    
+  };
+};
+
+
+/**
+ * gets a CSRF token by hitting github's login form
+ * @return {String} CSRF token
+ */
+var getAuthenticityToken = function() {
+  var login = githubLogin();
+  jar.parseHeaders(login.headers);
+  return encodeURIComponent(cheerio.load(login.body)('[name=authenticity_token]').val());
+};
+
+/**
+ * runs curl request to perform login action
+ * @return {String} github response headers
+ */
+var getGithubLoginResponseHeaders = function() {
+  if(!USERNAME) { return; }
+  var authenticity_token = getAuthenticityToken();
+  return childProcess.execSync(['curl',
+    'https://github.com/session',
+    
+    '-v',
+
+    '-H',
+    '"Pragma: no-cache"',
+
+    '-H',
+    '"Origin: https://github.com"',
+
+    '-H',
+    '"Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate"',
+
+    '-H',
+    '"Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.8"',
+
+    '-H',
+    '"Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1"',
+
+    '-H',
+    '"User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_11_1) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/46.0.2490.86 Safari/537.36"',
+
+    '-H',
+    '"Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded"',
+
+    '-H',
+    '"Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,*/*;q=0.8"',
+
+    '-H',
+    '"Cache-Control: no-cache"',
+
+    '-H',
+    '"Referer: https://github.com/"',
+
+    '-H',
+    '"Cookie: ' + jar.get() + '"',
+
+    '-H',
+    '"Connection: keep-alive"',
+
+    '--data',
+    '"utf8=%E2%9C%93&authenticity_token=' + authenticity_token + '&login=' + USERNAME + '&password=' + PASSWORD + '"',
+
+    '2>&1'
+  ].join(' ')).toString();
+};
+
+var headers = getGithubLoginResponseHeaders();
+
+jar.parseHeaders(headers);
+
+if(USERNAME) { module.exports = jar.get(); }

+## Configuring a custom message
+
+If you find the default PR comment a bit dry, it is possible to configure an external message generator which will be called prior to invoking the PR comment. Put a file called message.js in the root of your running mention-bot instance, that looks something like this:

+var util = require('util');
+
+module.exports = function(reviewerList, mentionSentenceBuilder) {

nit: space after `if`
you are inconsistent in the way you name things. Sometimes you put Async at the end sometimes not. Can you pick one and use it everywhere? My preference is to remove Async suffix everywhere
so good, no more indentation because of all those nested functions :)

Do you mean the async function prefix? The pattern I was following was to only use it where I need it. The async prefix is required in order to use await within the function. For functions like getRepoConfig which make an async request but just return a promise and don't use await, I opted not to use it. Although I am not opposed to adding it to these functions which do the request. Removing it everywhere is not an option because it is required to use await.

@CarlRosell @vjeux should we make this `return defaultOwners || fallbackOwners;` (or something similar) instead, in order to also have  support for the fallback notify users mechanism (being introduced in this PR) when `findPotentialReviewers` is disabled?
What do you guys think?

I'm not really sure what that would solve. As if you don't want to find potential users then you could just use the `alwaysNotifyForPaths` instead. Or am I missing something here :point_up: ?
When adding this feature my initial though was to change the config to something like

``` json
 "notifyForPaths": [
    {
      "name": "ghuser", 
      "files": ["src/js/**/*.js"],
      "always": true
    }
  ]
```

But that would have broken the API totally for the end user. This is to keep the old behavior and just add another feature. 
We might change the variable names to something like (`defaultOwners => alwaysNotifiedUsers` and `fallbackOwners => fallbackNotifiedUsers`) to make it clear what they are.

I get what you're saying, and that's definitely doable with `alwaysNotifyForPaths` - but is it the right way to do it?
Imho from a consistency perspective it's not, what I mean is that we currently support different flows (with `findPotentialReviewers` being enabled/disabled) and using these settings differently depending on the flow we're going with, might be kind of misleading to the end user.

The way I see this is:

> Find potential reviewers is enabled, .mention-bot uses blame history
> Always notify for paths is set, goes through that map of files/users and sees who needs to be additionally notified
> Fallback notify for paths is set, if no user found so far based on the two above, notify these set of users

or:

> Find potential reviewers is disabled, .mention-bot skips blame history
> Always notify for paths is set, goes through that map of files/users and sees who needs to be notified by default
> Fallback notify for paths is set, if no user found so far based on the previous one, notify these set of users

Meaning that based on the above, `fallbackNotifyForPaths` is used consistently independently of the flow we're going through instead of the current behaviour where it's only used when `findPotentialReviewers` is enabled forcing the user to set the "fallback notify for paths" mechanism in "always notify for paths" - right?

Let me know if I'm missing something.

Anyway, thanks for adding support for this, I definitely think it's useful :+1:
In case we don't wanna integrate this in the `findPotentialReviewers` (disabled) flow, should we have this being defined below? Otherwise we're running/setting it here for no reason.

body:
Thanks Christopher, I'll address your comments asap.

Ian

On 22 Aug 2016 10:59 pm, "Christopher Chedeau" notifications@github.com
wrote:

> In environment.js:
> 
> > @@ -0,0 +1,26 @@ > +"use strict" > + > +function
> > checkEnvironmentForConfig(config:Object) : Object {
> 
> you don't have @flow on the file, so : Object doesn't do anything fyi
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.

An easier way to solve this is to use the spread operator to do that logic for you:

``` js
{
  ...defaultConfig,
  ...customConfig
}
```

the `...` will override all the default values when a custom one exists

I'm really thankful for all the tests you added but in this case, I don't think that they are a good trade-off.
- With my suggested change, the logic in the function now becomes a one liner that is unlikely going to get a lot of issues.
- I don't really want to extract that logic out into its own separate file for now.
- The tests you wrote are unlikely to catch bugs and probably going to cause more work to keep them updated (see more inline)

When the next person is going to want to add another option, s/he is going to grep the project for an existing one and see 3 lines in this file, that do not really matter.

I would recommend to test cases such as number, array, boolean, string with random names instead of the full config.
you want to cleanup that global to what it was before otherwise it's going to mess up subsequent tests
You should clear out the environment variable explicitly, otherwise it's confusing what this test is doing (nothing?)
